review.title: On Context-Dependent Clustering of Bandits
review.abstract: We investigate two context-dependent clustering techniques for content recommendation based on exploration-exploitation strategies in contextual multi-armed bandit settings. Our algorithms dynamically group users based on the items under consideration and, possibly, group items based on the similarity of the clusterings induced over the users. The resulting algorithm thus takes advantage of preference patterns in the data in a way akin to collaborative filtering methods. We provide an empirical analysis on extensive real-world datasets, showing scalability and increased prediction performance over state-of-the-art methods for clustering bandits. For one of the two algorithms we also give a regret analysis within a standard linear stochastic noise setting.

sections.text: Our approach significantly loosens the constraints and requirements of previous work (e.g. (Cesa-Bianchi et al., 2013; Gentile et al., 2014; Nguyen & Lauw, 2014; Li et al., 2016; Wu et al., 2016) and offers much greater flexibility in dealing with practical situations such as the inclusion or exclusion of users. Under additional assumptions about the way data is generated, we delivered a crisp regret analysis depending on the expected number of clusters across users, a natural context-dependent idea of the (statistical) difficulty of the learning task. These theoretical results are further reinforced in the sparse user model scenario, which shows improved boundaries. We conducted an extensive experimental comparison across a number of production and real data sets, further highlighting the (statistical) difficulty of the learning task.

metadata.abstractText: We investigate a novel cluster-of-bandit algorithm CAB for collaborative recommendation tasks that implements the underlying feedback sharing mechanism by estimating the neighborhood of users in a context-dependent manner. CAB makes sharp departures from the state of the art by incorporating collaborative effects into inference as well as learning processes in a manner that seamlessly interleaving explore-exploit tradeoffs and collaborative steps. We prove regret bounds under various assumptions on the data, which exhibit a crisp dependence on the expected number of clusters over the users, a natural measure of the statistical difficulty of the learning task. Experiments on production and real-world datasets show that CAB offers significantly increased prediction performance against a representative pool of state-of-the-art methods.
